'''Ethics''', also known as '''moral philosophy''', is a branch of [[philosophy]] that involves systematizing, defending, and recommending concepts of right and wrong behavior.<ref>http://www.iep.utm.edu/ethics/</ref>
     
Major areas of study in ethics include:<ref>http://www.iep.utm.edu/ethics/</ref>
 
Major areas of study in ethics include:<ref>http://www.iep.utm.edu/ethics/</ref>

Line 11: Line 11:      
==Meta-ethics==
 
==Meta-ethics==
−
{{Main,|Meta-ethics}}
+
{{Main|Meta-ethics}}
 
Meta-ethics is a field within ethics that seeks to understand the nature of [[normative ethics]]. The focus of meta-ethics is on how we understand, know about, and what we mean when we talk about what is right and what is wrong.
 
Meta-ethics is a field within ethics that seeks to understand the nature of [[normative ethics]]. The focus of meta-ethics is on how we understand, know about, and what we mean when we talk about what is right and what is wrong.
    −
Meta-ethics came to the fore with [[George Edward Moore|G.E. Moore]]'s famous work ''[[Principia Ethica]]'' from 1903. In it he first wrote about what he called ''the [[naturalistic fallacy]]''. Moore was seen to reject [[Naturalism (philosophy)|naturalism]] in ethics, in his [[Open Question Argument]]. This made thinkers look again at second order questions about ,ethics. Earlier, the Scottish philosopher [[David Hu,me]] had put forward a similar view on the difference between [[Is-ought problem|facts and values]].
+
Meta-ethics came to the fore with [[George Edward Moore|G.E. Moore]]'s famous work ''[[Principia Ethica]]'' from 1903. In it he first wrote about what he called ''the [[naturalistic fallacy]]''. Moore was seen to reject [[Naturalism (philosophy)|naturalism]] in ethics, in his [[Open Question Argument]]. This made thinkers look again at second order questions about ethics. Earlier, the Scottish philosopher [[David Hume]] had put forward a similar view on the difference between [[Is-ought problem|facts and values]].
     
Studies of how we know in ethics divide into [[Cognitivism (ethics)|cognitivism]] and [[non-cognitivism]]; This is similar to the contrast between [[descriptivist theory of names|descriptivists]] and non-descriptivists. Non-cognitivism is the claim that when we judge something as right or wrong, this is neither true nor false. We may, e.g. be only expressing our emotional feelings about these things.<ref>http://www.iep.utm.edu/non-cogn/</ref> Cognitivism can then be seen as the claim that when we talk about right and wrong, we are talking about matters of fact.
 
Studies of how we know in ethics divide into [[Cognitivism (ethics)|cognitivism]] and [[non-cognitivism]]; This is similar to the contrast between [[descriptivist theory of names|descriptivists]] and non-descriptivists. Non-cognitivism is the claim that when we judge something as right or wrong, this is neither true nor false. We may, e.g. be only expressing our emotional feelings about these things.<ref>http://www.iep.utm.edu/non-cogn/</ref> Cognitivism can then be seen as the claim that when we talk about right and wrong, we are talking about matters of fact.
